Award.AwardTitle: Multiferroic Tunnel Junction with Active Dual Layer Barrier
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is jointly funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) and Ceramics Program (CER) in the Division of Materials Research (DMR).

Nontechnical Description
Nanoferronics is a new concept that combines ferroelectrics, which has spontaneous charge polarization, with spintronics, which utilize the electron spins to transport and store information. These new concepts can be used as multilevel multifunctional devices with new functionalities including electric control of spins. The project addresses a major materials challenge on how to increase the resistance on-and-off ratio of multiferroic tunnel junctions, a nanoferronic concept, by combining a very thin ferroelectric insulator and an interface layer as the barrier with magnetic tunnel junctions which have been used for magnetic recording and non-volatile memories. Success of the research can have significant impacts on realizing the new device concept and especially the combined memory-on-processor approach. The educational goals of the project are to provide educational and training opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students, especially for female and underrepresented minority undergraduate students, with a stimulating environment for interdisciplinary experience in physics, materials sciences, and engineering. The PI has many years of experience in advising female and underrepresented groups through several established programs on campus and will continue in those activities.

Technical Description
Multiferroic tunnel junctions combine magnetic tunnel junction with ferroelectric tunneling, and have shown many promising functionalities that can bring logic and memory into one device. The objective of the project is to design and fabricate a dual layer barrier in the multiferroic tunnel junctions with one ferroelectric barrier and a second interfacial layer. More specifically, by designing the barrier interface, a phase transition at the interface may be triggered and serve as a current filter to regulate the on-and-off state. The two major goals are (1) to increase the tunneling electroresistance, the resistance on-off ratio, and (2) to achieve the control of magnetic state by electrical field. With the second barrier layer, a much larger enhancement of the resistance ratio through the ferroelectric driven interface phase transition may be achieved. By combining the design and controlled growth of heterostructures of different magnetic and ferroelectric oxides, measurements of the interfacial states, and measurements of magnetic and transport properties of the devices, the project seeks to understand the mechanisms of the interfacial effect in enhancing tunneling electroresistance and magnetoelectric interaction in several systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoferronics is a new concept that combines ferroelectrics, which has spontaneous charge polarization, with spintronics, which utilize the electron spins to transport and store information. These new concepts can be used as multilevel multifunctional devices with new functionalities including multiferroic multistate memories, combined memory and processor in one device, and electric control of spins for spintronics. The project developed new material structure design in heterostructures which aimed to address a major materials challenge on how to increase the resistance on-and-off ratio of multiferroic tunnel junctions with the ferroelectric polarization reversal, and whether the spin polarization can be controlled electrically. The new multiferroic tunnel junctions combine two insulator barrier layers with one very thin ferroelectric layer and another interface layer near a phase transition in magnetic tunnel junctions. Magnetic tunnel junctions have been used for magnetic recording and non-volatile memories. Utilizing the ferroelectric driven interfacial phase transition of the combined barrier, the resistance difference between the different states has been greatly enhanced. The project has achieved several important results (1) demonstrating Quaternary resistance states, which resulted from the two relative magnetic alignment directions of the electrodes and the two ferroelectric polarization directions of the barrier, with significant increase in the resistance ratio; (2) demonstrating Octonary resistance states in the device utilizing additional stable non-collinear magnetic configurations; (3) demonstrating large ferroelectric control of the transport spin polarization; (4) selectively probed the interface magnetization of BaTiO3/La0.7Sr0.3MnO3and SrTiO3/ La0.5Ca0.5MnO3 interfaces and discovered a new spin-polarized current injection induced interface magnetoelectric effect, which can cause a sudden transition of spin alignment; (5) realizing high mobility electron gases at the interfaces of some insulating metal oxides. These research results have significant impacts on realizing the new multiferroic device concepts and especially the combined memory-on-processor approach using a new material structure design. The project has provided training for six undergraduate students, including a female student, one high school teacher, two graduate students, including an underrepresented minority student, with a stimulating environment for interdisciplinary experience in physics, materials sciences, and nanofabrication.  These efforts will have a major impact on the students’ research experience and the future of STEM workforce. In particular, training of female and underrepresented minority students, will have a significant impact on increasing the diversity in the STEM field.
